page.title: 12WILBERFOSS DUTCH ELM DISEASE
page.content: Many of the elms in Wilberfoss have died from Dutch Elm Disease. In the York area it has been quite serious with85% of trees infected. Trees which are found to have the disease should be cut down and the whole tree, especially the bark, burned.Trees can be saved, say the Forestry Commission by spraying against elm bark beetle as soon as any disease is found in elms close to each other. The loss of elms has had a very bad effect on the environment, as elms were once very common in the area, particularly in hedgerows, but it is hoped that lime trees may be planted as a substitute for lost elms. Many rookeries have been lost and the birds now have to nest in trees which are not to their liking.
